description: Late 15th century, from Medieval Latin dēfalcātiōnem, accusative singular of dēfalcātiō (literally “cutting off, lopping off with a sickle”), nominalization of dēfalcō, from Latin dē (“off”) + falx (“sickle, scythe, pruning hook”), from which also English falcate (“sickle-shaped”).
Surface analysis is defalcate +‎ -ion (“the act of”).

entries.meaning: (law) The act of cancelling part of a claim by deducting a smaller claim which the claimant owes to the defendant.
